President Joe Biden has emphasized the importance of education as a key driver of economic growth and social equity. During the election campaign, he pledged to invest $775 billion in early childhood education, K-12 education and higher education over ten years, with a focus on increasing funding for Title I schools (those serving low-income communities) and investing in teacher preparation and support. His administration has also outlined plans to expand access to dual-enrollment programs and community colleges, as well as forgive student loan debt and provide free community college education.

The Biden administration has also indicated a focus on improving the quality of education, as well as its accessibility. This could potentially include increased funding for educational research and innovation, adopting new approaches to assessment and accountability, and further investment in technology and infrastructure to support remote learning.

It is also possible that the Biden administration will adopt measures to address systemic inequalities in education and support the needs of marginalized communities. This could include initiatives such as diversifying the teaching workforce, investing in early childhood education resources in low-income communities, and increasing funding for programs that provide support to students with disabilities or English language learners.

Overall, it seems likely that the Biden administration will place an emphasis on supporting and expanding access to education across the board, potentially with a focus on measures to address inequities and ensure that all students have equal opportunities to succeed. However, the specifics of the administration's educational policy agenda remain to be seen, and will likely be shaped by ongoing political negotiations and competing policy priorities.
